column1: Before 24 July 2020, will it be officially announced that the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics and/or Paralympics will be postponed, canceled, and/or relocated?
column5: ['Yes, the Olympic Games only', 'Yes, the Paralympic Games only', 'Yes, both', 'No']
column6: ['Health', 'Sports']

In the present circumstances and based on the information provided by the WHO today, the IOC President and the Prime Minister of Japan have concluded that the Games of the XXXII Olympiad in Tokyo must be rescheduled to a date beyond 2020 but not later than summer 2021. https://www.olympic.org/news/joint-statement-from-the-international-olympic-committee-and-the-tokyo-2020-organising-committee
It's confirmed and the question isn't closed yet so I might as well make this final update https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/52020134
Definitely postponed

More historically-relevant countries are stepping-down due to covid-19 potential exposure to their athletes.
I found out, Minutes after updating my forecast, that Canada has withdrawn from the Olympics. That sensible action has change my opinion and, as a result, my forecast.

After the weekend's stats, I'm blown away by the devastating effect COVID is having countries and communities. I wonder if the best-case scenario would be a postponement. I'm less optimistic than I was on Friday.

There seems to be no chance of gatherings of this size happening within the next few months, and the decision for the Olympics/Paralympics will have to be made within those months. The size of the gathering even without attending fans is so large that accommodations will not work, so I believe they will certainly be canceled completely or postponed (though not simply relocated).

the go/no-go point will be long before the date of the start of the games and given the outlook at the moment, the idea of people from all over the world suddenly travelling en masse, meeting in one location, mingle, socialise then all leave to return home and potentially carry the virus is unthinkable. The precautionary principle will prevail and it will be posponed for a year.
Games postponed until 2021.Just off the wire.
"postponement has been determined" until 2021. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/ioc-member-says-2020-tokyo-olympics-will-be-postponed-likely-2021

It's outright being reported that the Olympics are being delayed, but technically there's no word on the Paralympics (I'd say the probability is more like 0.5% that it's just the Olympics but I only have integer values) https://twitter.com/usatodaysports/status/1242140945396662273

Cancellation looking increasingly likely, adjusting forecast accordingly: https://www.forbes.com/sites/isabeltogoh/2020/03/23/japans-prime-minister-hints-olympics-will-be-postponed-due-to-coronavirus/#45e21321af70
Update from dick pound
As major countries start pulling out of the Olympic Games, and with no signs of Covid-19 slowing down anytime soon, it’s almost impossible to imagine these events happening as planned.

In my first forecasts, I stated that there was no chance that the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics would be cancelled, postponed or relocated. I provided an explanation in my forecast on March 5, 2020. The WHO declared COVID-19 to be a pandemic on March 11, 2020. Since then, much has changed around the world.

https://apnews.com/b7b71576eddb82422929f19d7fb32f44 A virus is very small and the gritted teeth of the forced smile on a prime minister are no barrier to it. Abe has been asserting that all shall be well and all shall be well and all manner of things shall be well, but the IOC will not wish to run the Games with no athletes, even if they were okay with no spectators.

Canada has pulled out of the games today, and the world athletics body is also calling for postponement. As athletics is one of the central events of the Olympics, I think these recent factors point towards postponing the Games, if not abandoning the 2020 Games entirely.
Another link indicating postponement is likely. http://www.globalconstructionreview.com/news/olympic-body-mulls-delay-tokyo-2020-pandemic-escal/

Increasing looks like this will be postponed as the peak of the Corona virus will still be ongoing or only just have abated by the time their are meant to go ahead. This is the path of least resistance as the contracts underpinning the organisation of the games apparently allow this.
https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/athletics/52002474
It's done. Canada is the first to pull out, but as the IOC delays the decision more countries will pull out. Games will slip to 2021.

Updating figures, as per last forecast, cannot see the games going ahead, there is just too much going on, teams and athletes need to prepare and might even fall ill, airlines and airports are not going to be ready, there is no vaccine in place. It would be great if it did, but the harsh reality is it will not

Stronger and stronger voices from within the sporting community against holding the Olympics this Summer. Canada has decided not to participate: https://olympic.ca/press/team-canada-will-not-send-athletes-to-games-in-summer-2020-due-to-covid-19-risks/

As Paralympics are held after Olympics, small chance only the Olympics will be impacted (i.e. postponed, canceled, or relocated). Very small chance the Paralympics will be impacted but not the Olympics.

With general calls to postpone Olympics for athletes and Japanese officials expressing more of a willingness to postpone, updated to reflect higher likelihood of postponement. I could still see Olympics moved to after Paralympics
According to article linked below, Canada will not send athletes to Tokyo Olympics and calls for the games to be postponed for 1 year. This makes it even more likely the games will be postponed.
Same as for coachella, world virus news, complications, economy news, olympic village is a no-go, ...
Canada pulled out of the games

Unlikely to be cancelled but seem certain to move now. https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2020/mar/22/ioc-expected-to-make-decision-on-tokyo-2020-olympics-within-four-weeks?CMP=soc_567&fbclid=IwAR2IxOxNQ4eWEhmhNFNqa-rHPNMsTQNolb5RHn0qcYRjy0Hkw8KAy92ft2E

If it is going to be determined in the next 4 weeks, they are going to postpone. :(

Even if COVID spike subsides before the games start, no vaccine and uninfected populations mean that large international gatherings will need to be prohibited, as they will be the most likely causes of resurgence.
Failure to respond when needed has increased the risk of cancellation. Only chance for the games to continue as scheduled is if outcome of the efforts to contain have better than expected results.

Pressure is building from countries Olympic Committees and Athletes. Probably just postpone.

There is a lot of pressure on IOC and the Japanese government to not cancelling the Olympics Games. But the reality of the covid-19 outbreak worldwide and the timing could force a postponement, which is including in the No column.
travel implications, too many athletes affected, too much work yet to be done amid lockdowns
To bring so many people together would be madness, given the severity of the virus
A study is started. The resultaat can be presented as a technical advice. Hé who decides can follow the advice and safe his standing as a wise person.
With 3 months minimum before any return to competition, I can see no scenario where games go ahead
Updating forecast due to increasing likelihood of postponement.
the torch was passed but it will not happen

I keep seesawing back and forth, if the call was made right now, it would be cancelled. What we're trying to predict is if the world will be in a safer space in three months time in an environment that lacks consistency and with nothing that is historically similar. My feeling is that every COVID challenge we undertake here is underpinned with a large dose of conjecture.
https://www.skysports.com/share/11961615
Coronavirus and the U.S. Olympic Qualifying Conundrum

When taking into account that fact that qualifications need to be done beforehand, it seems very likely that it will be cancelled. Also, it seems like the pandemic will need to be controlled in most countries in order to hold them, which seems unlikely. There are going to be waves in different countries at different times.
It will be Tokyo 2021 - as no one will be able to qualify, travel or attend in 2020. We'll all be watching movies at home and tending our gardens.

USA Swimming wrote the IOC and called for a delay until 2021. Many countries are on lockdown because of the virus. Probability of delay increasing, but it could run its course to allow an Olympics without spectators during the summer. That in itself would be a boon to the world if everyone were engaging in social isolation.

Reasons that it will be canceled/postponed/relocated: - Other major sporting events have canceled/postponed - Qualifying events have been canceled/postponed - Athletes have not been able to train fully to prepare - Some countries may not be able to travel to Japan due to coronavirus, particularly those in southern hemisphere - Some athletic programs have petitioned not to go (USA Track and Field, USA Swimming)
Things have changed a lot in a short amount of time
The below article outlines how problematic cancelling and postponing the Olympics is. The complications involved are unprecedented. Those saying with 100% sure are extremizing beyond belief.

In a showdown over public safety, the organizers of the Tokyo Olympics are facing a remarkable groundswell of criticism and pushback from their own athletes, fans and national Olympic officials, who are increasingly and unusually vocal in calling for a postponement.
Moving further towards posteponement, since there is a lot of pressure for that now https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/21/sports/olympics/tokyo-olympics-coronavirus-cancel.html

US sports interests now weighing in that these events be postponed. Brazil has also weighed in recommending postponements. Link here https://thehill.com/homenews/news/488797-usa-track-field-calls-for-tokyo-olympics-to-be-postponed
Seems like the IOC and the Tokyo Organising Committee are hell bent on not cancelling or rescheduling the games https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/19/sports/olympics/olympics-coronavirus-bach-ioc.html

By July the athletes will have been unable to train properly and won’t have done any competition prior. While that may make for a fascinating games, the athletes will want to know how they are doing. And if a lot of them have been sick given the effect on lungs, they may need more time to recover to compete at such a high standard.

Mounting pressure and social responsibility are going to play a major role with four months to go. The risk to athletes and the public comes off as tone-deaf and the PR optics runs counter to the spirit of the games. "Postponed, cancelled and/or relocated" is broad enough to be likely. The disruption to training and travel plans alone leaves us questioning what countries can/will send representatives and how competitive these games ultimately will be if held on 24 July.

Revising estimates to take into account the increasing pressure to cancel. From experience with the moving of marathon from Sapporo to Tokyo, Thomas Bach is the key player in this decision rather than a reasoned council. So lowered slightly for uncertainty.
Why not Tokyo 2021?
The pandemic will still be out of control.
Qualifyers are being cancelled and may force the IOC's hand
I struggle to see how the games can continue. Seems strange to decide on one without the other as they are closely linked. Japan will want to ensure the investment in the games gets used.
Update: More and louder appeals
Because of the governments use of the coronavirus "crisis" to increase controls of the private means of production. They need people to be fearful to obtain their consent to submit to authority.

This just in: https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2020/03/19/2020-tokyo-oympics-japanese-official-calls-for-postponement/2881032001/
The most significant article yet, A Japanese committee official has broken ranks to call for it to be cancelled.

Acting only on one of the two would make no sense, hence 0% there. The likelihood of the virus and the fear being zeroed by then is very remote, hence almost surely both. A small hope that a "white swan" event happens and kills the virus leaves a 5% chance that the world will go back to normal before July.

I believe that Japan is currently under-testing it’s population and that will lead to a delayed recognization of what is a massive problem for all developed countries and ultimately a postponement or cancellation of the games prior to July 24th.

The Olympic committee has been critical of Japan’s attempt to keep the 2020 games and even the Japanese conversation has softened in recent days from “it will go on” to something more like “we will find the best option.” There are no events for athletes to polish and train at, so even if the organizers were truly stubborn, the Olympics would be an embarrassing flop if they went on as planned. I think it’s taking a long time to come to this decision based on the sink cost fallacy— Japan’s National conversation about the 2020 Olympics has been omnipresent all the time that I have lived here (5years). Once the decision is announced, Japan will probably begin to do a better job regarding Covid-19. General public opinion here is that the government is downplaying it because they had wanted to preserve the Olympics. That, and Japan’s lack of a CDC (meaning bureaucrats were responsible for assessing the risks of Covid-19, not an informed panel of experts) led to digging of heels in on the Olympics for longer than it should have been. But Japan is very sensitive to their national reputation and the criticism that attempting to keep the 2020 Olympics is irresponsible will probably make it easier for the government to save face about changing their direction.
Both will be either delayed or cancelled as there is very little time for worldwide athletes to practice or qualify with the Covid19 still spreading and at an upward trend worldwide.
There's no way around it. Who wants to go anyway?

With the virus taking hold, I believe the games will get cancelled/postponed. However due to the weight of history and how many olympics have happened despite bad world affairs, I think there's a realm in which competitors will compete in some events that are more solitary in nature (races, lifting, etc) - I see paralympic games requiring more person-person interactions and could slightly cause them to get cancelled with the main olympics undergoing some version of social distancing but still enabling track and field events.
Continuing the move towards both being postponed (or cancelled etc), since it seems there is more pressure there (based off a BBC News report) for a postponement.

"Japanese Olympic Committee (JOC) board member Kaori Yamaguchi has called for the Tokyo Olympics to be postponed because athletes are unable to prepare adequately as a result of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, she told the Nikkei newspaper." https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-outbreak-03-19-20-intl-hnk/h_df09a545c59749bf85069a58d10becbf

Even if Covid-19 cases decrease in specific geographies by late June/early July the likelihood that it is still active in many others. As such, the risk of re-sparking the pandemic by bringing athletes, spectators, and press from so many nations together is too high to justify.
It appears that the olympic comittee is kicking the can down the road. Keep that up for another few weeks and the decision is effectively made.

Pandemic growing... it seems from research the pestilence can come in waves. I believe by that time a second wave will have started and countries athletes will not be able to attend due to various differing circumstances.

Athletes are already very uncomfortable about staging the games. There is no fair solution now, and several countries will still be in the grip of the virus come July/August. Japan cannot afford to risk thousands of athletes bringing more disease. Also, the spectacle of empty stadiums would look very bad. I’m sceptical that anywhere else could stage a worthwhile games at this late stage, so my view is that they will be postponed until next year.
Oops, the previous adjustment wasn't enough.
To stay ahead of the crowd, mostly :P But also because it is getting worse in the West now.
Given the COVID concerns, it's unlikely that teams could even train as a group for, let alone participate in the Olympics & Paralympics.
both because of corona virus may be at his highest infection rate.

I think the Japanese government is wishing on a star here, but I would guess the economic echoes and even reinfections are going to prevent most countries from joining, or even wanting to join. Even if restrictions are lifted, how many people are going to second guess their trip?

Been factoring considerations more from the athletes perspectives. Preparation times are too tight. If you've ever been a highly competitive athlete, you'd know that you a pyramid training schedule is put in place to time your 'peak' at events like these. With restrictions on movement, this will throw a lot of people's pre-event schedules off like crazy.

Japan saying they still want to go ahead, but I really cannot see it, CV19 will go on for months, even as some countries settle down others are going to start up and if there is not one big time out it is going to carry on and on
Athletes beginning to complain. No training, olypmic trials disrupted, etc. https://apnews.com/f76abb6c37fb0f8a278910644023625c
Apparently some increased interest by the Olympic Committees in changing schedules
The sunk costs - they cannot afford to delay the games While COVID19 is changing the world, to not have the games shows it's stopping the world
increasing the probability from 25% cancel to 30% cancel for olympics because the japanese deputy PM talks abt curse
Update: Increased international pressure from
Adjusting after yesterday's announcement that the games WILL go ahead. It helped my confidence, but there's still a realistic chance of it being postponed.

Unless there is some sort of vaccine, or better, cure, the only way the games can be played is if there is some way to put space between everyone, which is doubtful, especially for games where teams of players play, like basketball. Perhaps isolating the athletes for two weeks before hand? But then there are all the other people necessary to officiate and broadcast the games, as well as feed and service all these athletes, they would need to be isolated too. Huge effort just to play games, and perhaps they can just postpone to maybe September 2021, assuming a vaccine can be developed by then. Plus, part of the spectacle is having the huge crowds participating, and there is no way to do that, there can be no audience, as that risks infecting the players. So I think both are postponed.
Seems impossible that enough countries will be in a state to send teams such that it's considered a viable and symbolically valid contest by this date.

Japan is handling the cases well, but it is still ongoing globally. Bringing Olympians, trainers, press, and spectators in from countries who are still in the midst of COVID19 response alongside those who may not have been exposed would be far too risky.

It is unlikely for only 1 of the Games to be postponed/cancelled considering 1 month between them. Hence putting small probability there. However, given that Olympics start 1 month earlier, am rating that slightly higher.

We judge the future based on our perceptions today. And today COVID-19 is a scary beast that forces social distancing, closing schools, travel bans and economy downturn. According to WHO and CDC (and in our minds), the whole world is on fire, even countries like China and South Korea, which apparently got it under control (though may lose it). IOC insistence on Olympic Games seems irresponsible and careless
Update: Irrespective of what officials are saying, there is more and more evidence for postponement among both participants and organizing committees
https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/51943083 - Athletes frustrated and training impacted but ... https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/51924635 - Japan still planning complete games

Some countries have recently started cancelling training for their athletes, and the Japanese response to the Coronavirus has been fairly opaque so for all we know it could be a ticking time bomb. Additionally, the optics have changed the last few weeks as other large sporting events e.g. Euro 2020, have been postponed.
My Take on the Olympics:

It may seem like I'm flip-flopping with this question, but I had incomplete data yesterday when I updated (My own fault) Yes, Japan was strained, but they're coping well with 824 cases on a flattening curve. 300+ of those cases were as a result of a floating petri dish called the "Diamond Princess"
Nudging the No a touch higher based on the IOC statement from today https://www.olympic.org/news/communique-from-the-international-olympic-committee-ioc-regarding-the-olympic-games-tokyo-2020.
Updating based on articles today. Especially regarding Euro 2020

Forget about it! NYT article today convinced me it cannot happen for so many reasons. Participants cannot train, participants cannot be selected in competitive trials, people cannot travel to compete or watch. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/03/17/sports/olympics/tokyo-olympics-in-july.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

I think the developments are such that it is unlikely the games will go on. Japan will not be in a position to medically support the games come summer. The vice-chair was dx'd today with covid-19. Just like all the other major events, this will be put off for 12 months.
Moving towards both being cancelled, since the outbreak is more severe seeming (and potential actions longer-lasting) than I assumed when making my initial prediction.
Got my boxes mixed up. Never get old.
Increase in yes based on global shutdown amid Covid 19.

https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/51924635 The Honourable PM seems to believe that diseases are susceptible to optimism and so if he talks up his hopes, the virus will decamp. One is inclined to doubt the accuracy of his major premise. The IOC will hear a WHO, which like Horton's will turn out to be real.

According to the latest news, Japan is in a bit of a dilemma. However, as the pandemic is now reaching the USA, and if the China experience is going to teach us something, it won't be over anytime soon. Abe or not Abe. The Olympic games without the USA won't be Olympic games.
Upon second thought, if the Olympics are cancelled, so would the Paralympics. And I assigned a very very small chance to both going ahead, of course.

the 15/03/2020 statement from the PM of Japan was that the Olympics would go ahead on time. But on the 17th, he made a new statement following a G7 leaders' video conference about coronavirus, and he dodged mentioning timelines for the Olympics. I think its a high 60s percent chance of being postponed.

With the recent spike in infection rates, I need to adjust this forecast - there is a higher chance that the virus will affect a no-go decision in Japan. If the infection rate starts to flatten soon, it'll be back on. However, it has to flatten soon in Japan where the virus is straining their infrastructure.
First, getting rid of the "Olympic Games only" and "Paralympic Games only" options with 2% each. It seems to me extremely unlikely that either of them will take place as planned but not the other.
Increasing the likelihood of cancellation/postponement in light of the advancing COVID-19 situation and effect on qualification and summer travel.

As of today they are still adamant they will go ahead. But they have also ruled out empty stadiums which sets the bar higher for them. They are gambling that some kind of normality will have been restored by the time of the games, at least in the host country. But Japan seems to be managing the epidemic less aggressively than many countries in Europe now. Increasing cancellation chance to 30% and will monitor.

Something must change, the fewer changes the better implies that the Paralympics stays on schedule and the main event begins in Sept / Oct. Even this plan is risky, but at least threads the needle with least disruptions.
I'm considering the shutdown of training centres and the psychological aspects of national Olympic Committees concerning the health of the athletes under their charge.

"A public-opinion poll published by Kyodo News on Monday showed 70% of respondents said the Olympics couldn’t go ahead as planned, while 25% said they could. Online surveys late last week by two newspapers each found around 60% of respondents supported delaying the Games, while fewer than 20% thought they should open as scheduled on July 24...Olympic organizers have maintained that the Tokyo Games remain on track...International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach plans to hold a conference call Tuesday with international sports federations to discuss the coronavirus crisis, according to Agence-France Presse." https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-polls-show-many-japanese-want-tokyo-olympics-to-be-postponed-11584355170

I like the argumentation presented here [1]. If there is a delay then it won't be for the paralympic games. A lot depends on the normalisation of the situation. I'm confident that it'll have wrapped up by August and even possible before July. There's still time to decide for the IOC and I assume they won't come to a conclusion before April - even though the pressure to cancel may surge everyday a decision has not been made.

While the Japanese are very clear that they have no intention to move the games the number of Japanese Covid-19 cases are increasing at what still appears to be exponential growth. There will also be added pressure from other governments that do not want to heighten the risk or the rate of infection within their own countries through tourism to the games. If we see governments suggesting that they will boycott the event then there will be a huge pressure to postpone of cancel the games. The financial loss to Japan and the cost will be huge an as such I cannot see the Japanese stance changing.
Pressure is mounting, British athletes are requesting a decision soon. This week will be significant for this question.

Another major tournament the euro 2020 is being discussed by the committee abt possibly postponing it. See https://www.theguardian.com/football/2020/mar/12/uefa-to-consider-postponing-euro-2020-until-next-summer-over-coronavirus The more likely other major sports tournaments are postponed or cancelled, the more likely the same applies to olympics because international pressure.

The Olympics have been cancelled 5 times in their modern history, so it would not be unprecedented, but has been reserved for cases of war. However, pretty much all major sports have suspended or cancelled events, so we are dealing with an anomalous situation. Based on the rate and expectation for the virus spread, I think that that weighs heavily into rescheduling the games. However, based on the level of containment in China, I could have some hope that worldwide totals will reduce to a level the IOC would be able to make a good case argument that the risks associated with the games would be low. I could see IOC moving the games to after para-Olympics to buy more time for virus to pass. I could also see a scenario where IOC gets it wrong and after an outbreak after Olympics causing the moving of para-Olympic games

If the british government is even close to being right with their assessment, AND this is consensus with the WHO AND IOC listens to WHO, there is no way to hold the games as planned. They said, they have to make a decision in the next few weeks (2-3 months max), and that would be at height of numbers of new infections. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/15/uk-coronavirus-crisis-to-last-until-spring-2021-and-could-see-79m-hospitalised

Revising no down slightly, yes both up slightly. There is enough lead time to start thinking and planning - while it might be with no crowds and reduced athlete and support teams, I fully expect it will still go ahead.

The yes probability reflects the expected spread of covid-19 in countries outside of Japan meaning that athletes and, perhaps more critically, spectators may largely be coming from highly infected regions (UK, Germany, US etc), which would clearly cause an infection risk in Japan even if they can contain their current outbreak there. The chance of “no” reflects the possible contingencies that would allow the games to go ahead in a drastically reduced form, eg banning certain countries from sensing teams/spectators, having games without spectators. The probabilities for only one reflect the chance that there is a general intention to go ahead, but a specific (but unlikely) scenario details one set of games only, for example coronavirus infection of one organising committee or a specific group of athletes.
Abe is insisting that there will be no delay; but as stated by others, several logistical factors may impede the best of efforts.
Because it was announced today that it will go on.

Governments are panicking. Actually, the experts say that putting young people together is a good thing as it will help build herd immunity, but who needs experts seems to be the view of the populists now in charge
First forecast

Japan insistent that they won’t be postponed. It will be taken out of their hands if qualifiers continue to be postponed. It seems as if they would rather they go ahead with no spectators than not at all.

Preparation for Athletes and planning, organisation etc. is will be difficult/impossible in a lot of countris Such an assembling of millions of people from around the world will risk a second wave of Virus-spreading
i would say, until may the crisis is over and the normal life is going on. but it's not impossible, that's even the ioc must suspend the olympic.

Dropping my prediction slightly as my optimism and confidence wains. What I did not account for earlier was not the games themselves, but the effect on the preparation for the games. Not being able to meet, connect and work together will affect the preparation both for the Olympic preperation teams and the athletics teams. However, it's a significant world event and the world wants it to succeed, and I still believe strongly that the virus wil abate in time for the call NOT to cancel.

This may be too bullish, but it seems the Olympics requires too much international travel from too many countries to go ahead. Japan wants to make it happen, but even if their outbreak is under control (and that's a big if, they can't lockdown forever and a second spike would coincide with this timing exactly) I don't see how you can host such a large and international event without causing a big new outbreak right there and then. 20% because the Japanese government is so reluctant to call it off and has managed to stop the virus for now, but come May/June I don't see how it will be feasible to not cancel.

Trump has called for them to be postponed. The Japan government has said no. This one is on a knife edge. Qualifiers have taken place today in Britain for boxing. It seems as if they are planning for it to happen. Can see it staged without spectators.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-olympics-abe-idUSKBN2110G2
two way bet.
the corona virus will have peaked before that date

Sports teams are canceling seasons and events left and right because of COVID-19, however the Olympics represent one of the two most iconic sporting events in the world (World Cup being the other). The IOC will want to signal to Japan that their investment has not been a waste. Canceling on Japan, even if there is a risk, will have a chilling effect on future cities' decision to bid on an Olympic Games. The IOC board is a venial and selfish group of people, and they will be thinking about their organization long term. For its part, Japan may take robust moves to prevent spread of COVID-19 (it has held sumo events in empty stadiums), but it will not want to cancel based on the necessity to justify the expenditures it has incurred. The Olympics is several months down the road. Things could be quite manageable by then, or (25% chance) all of urban Japan could look like Philadelphia 1918.

Based on the low rates of COVID-19 in India now, the theory that transmissibility in warmer climates is lower seems reasonable. If new cases in North America and Europe slow coming into late spring and early summer supporting the theory, the probability the games will be canceled will be very low. Add to that the mortality rates to the young and fit now is also very low. I would, therefore, expect the majority of athletes will have only suffered mild symptoms if any at all if they become infected. The spectators may be a different issue, however, the majority of the money from the games comes from the broadcasters and advertisers, and not ticket sales, so limiting spectators shouldn't hurt too much. The Paralympics come later in the summer so the temperatures should still be good, and while the athletes are typically young and fit as well, there is more potential that some would suffer more from symptoms based on their underlying physical conditions. If that is widespread, a lack of athletes may disrupt the games, however, the withdrawal of up to 10% of the athletes would likely not cause the games to be canceled.

Interest in Japan and the games

The "Home City Contract" was signed by the International Olympic Committee (IOC), the city of Tokyo and the Japanese Olympic Committee in 2013. The contract give much leeway to the IOC to cancel (and probably to postpone and/or relocate) the Olympic Games. The IOC has to give local organizers, the city of Tokyo and the national Olympic committee 60 days notice to cancel the games.

A decision will have to be made by May, according to the IOC, so even if by May you think "it might still be ok by August", if things are bad in May there will probably have to cancel. The Olympics is obviously very rarely cancelled but there is precedent (1940). I can't think of any good reason why the Olympics and Paralympics would be considered differently. What pushes me towards "yes" is the fact that of course the Olympics involves participants and spectators from all over the world, so even if by May many countries have managed the problem and are seeing a very low number of cases, it seems likely that in many other countries the outbreak will still be raging.
The IOC has an Insurance against Games Cancellation, 800 Million. Only a fraction of the money involved, but it could make the decision easier.

Previous flu based viruses epidemics (in recent history) have not had the legs (of a marathon runner) to survive warmer temperatures. This may be causal, not as a result of the warm weather, but instead because the vaccines have been developed, deployed, administered and are working. So either the warm weather helps, or the science works, either way my observation is that there's a start in Oct/Nov and a decline by May/June the following year. I believe Covid will be in remission by the time the call is made, and that that the games will continue.

Forecast 2 My first forecast assumed that postponement was not a possibility given that no games have been postponed previously. A recent statement by the Japanese Olympic Minister[1] has forced me to revaluate this stance. In order to arrive at a new forecast I will take the average of the three scenarios: Not cancelled, postponed, and both cancelled (I have taken the stance that the postponement or cancellation of one but not the other should not currently be considered). Refer to previous forecast (linked below) for discussion of factors, which I do not believe this examination will affect (at least at present time)

Only the IOC can cancel the games. Japan has a contract to host the games in 2020 - the year. Consider a scenario where the Paralympics run as planned in August and the Olypyics FOLLOW in Sept/Oct. This provides a several month delay to the Olympics and keep the commitment for the Paralympics. Going ahead as planned would likely be a financial disaster for all concerned.

We seem to be playing off medical necessity against economic interests with most of these coronavirus questions, so despite Japan's suggestion that the Olympics be postponed & the reality that the event will create an infection hotspot, I'm cautiously moving down towards the 'No' position suggested by the IOC's statement of commitment. This move has been informed by four factors beyond those mentioned above :- 1) Japan's lack of a coronavirus stats update over the last 24hrs. Given the infection's expected trajectory, this has the appearance of political non-disclosure. 2) The seeming decision by the US and Britain to allow Covid19 to become endemic, which would make cancelling the Olympics pointless. 3) The huge economic investment by IOC nations. 4) The cultural adoption of a "We don't know enough about this virus to justify cancelling anything" rationale in countries making minimal attempts to contain the virus. The more embedded that attitude becomes, the more difficult it will become for wary leaders to invoke the precautionary principle, whether it applies to national borders, international trade or major public events.

There are two issues that need to be considered: 1)Organisers: They have invested a lot of money, hence, are more reluctant to make any changes. If a big porcentage of attendees decide to cancel their participation for fears of transmitting or being infected, then organisers will have to postpone the Olympic Games. For example, the World Mobile Congress in Barcelona was canceled as result of big international corporate attendees canceling their attendance. 2)Attendees: if the risk of becoming infected are higher, then possibly country olympic committees will cancel their participation for protecting their elite teams. It would be a catastrophe for any country, specially from the PR perspective, if an olympic athlete dies as result of COVID-19, either within or outside their country of origin. Different government countries start to enforce ban of big gathering of people in order to avoid further transmission of the virus. Cultural, musical and sport events have been canceled in many countries already. TV crews are also deciding to decline attendance to big events as result of COVID-19.

Base Rate: • 3 of the 31 Summer Olympics have been cancelled (due to WW1 and WW2), which provides a base rate 10% (if the Winter Olympics were include this rate would go down, but I have not included that here because the scale of the two is different and timing in the year when the Winter games are held may not provide the best comparison; furthermore, the Winter games are a relatively recent event) • Other Olympics with regional and global controversies were not cancelled (Zika, after 9/11, Beijing, London with security issues) 2020 Specific: • Spread within Japan: spread seems to have significantly slowed (See who daily reports) • Spread in China: spread outside of Hubei has slowed considerably with a few studies showing that their containment efforts have been very successful (when comparing the expected peak vs what has been see – I suppose you could quibble about reported vs actual numbers) (See who daily reports but I am unable to find that study again) • Spread elsewhere in the world: likely not contained in Iran; and possible parts of Italy and South Korea • Apparent deadlines and Virility: CFR has hovered around 2-4% depending on which country you are looking at. However, virility appears to be high and possibly as high as the common cold • IOC Statements: public musing that if spread is not contained by May, they may cancel but remain fully committed; it is also more likely that the events get cancelled rather than postponed or relocated (logistically it is not possible); furthermore, a number of games have faced controversy – 2016 Brazil had Zika, 2004 Athens were the first games after 9/11 [1] • Japanese Olympic Committee Statements; visiting athletes could be subject to quarantines upon arrival • Status of the prequalifying events: so far nothing has been cancelled but notably Russia is skipping all prequalifying tournaments. That being said, if these are not held, then it reduces the likelihood that the Olympics are held

There immense international buy in for the Olympics, and it has never been stopped/relocated/postponed for reasons outside of war.

Outside view: Olympics have only ever been cancelled because of war. Inside view 1: Both IOC and Japan have spent a lot of money and want to maximise their potential profits. They will be looking for all possible ways to keep the games on. Inside view 2: The Olympics have never happened during an epidemic with these exact characteristics and level of infection in the host country. Japan has 962 cases as of today and has been worried enough to shut down schools. Inside view 3: the way the Olympics is run would seem to make quick decision-making difficult, and if they are going to do anything they would have to do it quickly. Inside view 4: relocating would be too hard at this stage, and postponing would not necessarily offer any more certainty. So I will assume only cancellation is on the cards. Although the Paralympic games are two weeks later than the Olympics, I don't see any logic for cancelling one but not the other given that number of infected and trajectory of the epidemic are unknown for both dates.

Special measures likely to hamper preparations, regardless of event itself which would act as a global infection hub & risk destroying athletes' careers. Am leaving open a 15% chance the games will go ahead for political or economic reasons anyway. Since both the Olympics & Paralympics require similar global connectivity & disability doesn't necessarily imply greater health risk factors, it seems more likely both events would be canceled than just one.

The latest news are not encouraging, however, being Coronavirus subject to season, and we are a few months away, there maybe still time to contain the pandemic. Or else there will be many more serious problems.

Base rate games in the last 100 years - 3 cancellations due to war. Spanish flu and Zika did not lead to cancellation. Scale and spread of CoVid-19 significantly greater than Zika. Tokyo announced closure of schools, indicating real concerns. Predictions place peak infections around June. Only require a few large countries to disallow travel of athletes to have snowball effect. Current sporting events already postponed due to Covid-19.
The Olympics involves many mass gatherings and lots of international travel, the two worst things in a pandemic.

IMHO, the main problem now is not Japan or China, or S. Korea as these ones are getting a hold of their respective epidemics/outbreaks. The same goes for South East Asia. If the preventive measures hold, COVID-19 may be on the background, but not enough to prevent the Games. Plus the Japanese have capabilities to screen.
Sports enthusiast
